“The Way I Used To Be” by @ambersmithauthor 

Hello besties 🤍

How is everyone doing?

About to start this book, which has been on my tbr for quite some time.
I know it is going to be a hard book to get through, in terms of events, so make sure you read all the triggers before starting this one.

Has anyone read this?
What are your thoughts?

Happy Wednesday besties, hope you are all having a wonderful day. 🤍

💫 Kalenderluke 2:
Den fineste forsiden på bøkene jeg har lest i år. 

'the way I used to be' av Amber Smith. Forsiden (og tittelen) trakk meg til denne boka. Innholdet sto til stil med førsteinntrykket. Her er den avbildet i glansen den fortjener av noen av julelysene hjemme. 

Dessverre har den fått litt hard medfart da den ble glemt ute over natten en dag i vår 🙈

▷ The Way I Used To Be By Amber Smith
@ambersmithauthor 

▷ This book really amplifies the saying "one act can change your life" and that's what happened to Eden sadly. The stage's this book goes through is freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior year and seeing how much the traumatic experience changes Eden's life throughout the years of her high school experience. Reading this definitely had moments where it was too hard to read but it was worth it. It was quite a learning experience for me. If you have the time I would recommend giving this book a go for sure!

▷ TW: Rape

#bookstagram #bookstagrammer #booktok #bookreview #thewayiusedtobebook #sadbooks #youngadultbooks #youngadult #books

The Way I Used To Be by @ambersmithauthor . The novel is told in four parts of the main character Eden’s life. Her freshman, sophomore, junior and senior year. One night when Eden is 14, she is sexual assaulted by her brothers best friend. She doesn’t tell anyone about what happened. As she tries to tell her mother the fear from her assaulters threats stops her. So she carries the weight of the trauma alone. As the story evolves, you see how the trauma of the assault and the painful secret effects her relationships, her decisions and self worth. The book is a really hard read especially the chapter on her assault and Eden’s coping mechanisms. 

Eden is so strong, she’s real and imperfect. She was put simply, trying to cope with what had happened to her. Her experience is her own. I think the novel correctly shows the trauma that a rape leaves behind. It’s deeply emotional to read, as Eden is tormented by the lasting effects. But it also feels healing, as you see Eden process and work through her pain. 

This book touched my heart, I cried the whole way through. It is so painful to read but you can’t put it down. It’s a book that has really stuck with me. I felt so angry, sad and devastated reading it. It’s a moving and powerful novel. 

It is written so well Smith did a wonderful job. Whilst the book breaks my heart, I am so grateful a novel like this exists. It really helps young girls as it shines a light on these horrific experiences and perhaps brings some level of peace to survivors. Eden’s story is one that will always be close to my heart 💛💛. 

I highly recommend this one to everyone it’s truly worth it. 💛✨🌼🌻

🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟/5

Favourite Quote - “All these maybes swimming around my head make me think “maybe” could just be another word for hope.”

#bookrecs #bookstagram #bookreview #booklover #bookish #bookaddict#bookworm #booklove #bookrecommendations #bookcommunity #bookstagram #bookreview #bookrecommendation #thewayiusedtobe #thewayiusedtobebook

5/5 ⭐️

When I tell you this book was one of the most raw, emotional and powerful books I’ve ever read, I’m not lying. I’m starting this of with the big trigger warning: rape. The title of this book is the perfect way to describe how our main character, Eden goes through life after being raped. She is definitely not the person she used to be. Eden was quite a difficult character for me to understand, but you can’t understand a person if you’ve never experienced what they have. This was one of the first books that every page I turned, I just wanted to scream at her to tell somebody what she went through. But all she did was continuously hurt those she loved so deeply because, well, she was hurting too. Being a stand alone book, the character development is AMAZING. I truly felt like I learned a lot about how certain life altering moments can affect people. 

#bookstagram #bookblog #booktok #bookstagrammer #bookrecommendations #booksofinstagram #yabooks #yabookstagrammer #bookish #thewayiusedtobebook #ambersmithbooks #bookaddict

The way I used to be- Amber Smith
★ ★ ★ ★
“ And I’m trying so hard to just go back to my life. The way it used to be. The way I used to be.” 

CHECK TW! 
I think everyone has to read this book ones in there life. It’s such a meaningful story with unfortunately a common topic. It was an eye opener for me. Love every single one of you🫶🏻 

Story
Eden was always good at being good. Starting high school didn't change who she was. But the night her brother's best friend rapes her, Eden's world capsizes. What was once simple, is now complex. What Eden once loved-who she once loved-she now hates. What she thought she knew to be true, is now lies. Nothing makes sense anymore, and she knows she's supposed to tell someone what happened but she can't. So she buries it instead. And she buries the way she used to be. Told in four parts -freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior year-this provocative debut reveals the deep cuts of trauma. But it also demonstrates one young woman's strength as she navigates the disappointment and unbearable pains of adolescence, of first love and first heartbreak, of friendships broken and rebuilt, and while learning to embrace a power of survival she never knew she had hidden within her heart.

ꜱʏᴍʙᴏʟ ᴏꜰ ɢʀᴏᴡᴛʜ, ʜᴏᴘᴇ, ᴀɴᴅ ʜᴇᴀʟɪɴɢ.

“Be like a dandelion. Whenever they fall apart, they start again. Have hope.”  

this book captured my heart and pull me in the entire story. showed me a visual into a world of someone who got hurt, had lost hope, suffered through hardships only to find strength and faith to heal and grow again. this is a story of a young woman to find her strength in the aftermath of an assault. 

i cried, reading about her. she went through deep cuts after cuts. “a single act can change your life forever”, they said. in Eden’s story, in the course of 5 minutes in her life, that she was assaulted, sent her into a spiral of despair. times when she doesn’t recognised herself. 

“Whatever he thinks that I am, I'm not. And whatever he thinks my body is, it isn't. My body is a torture chamber. It's a f***ing crime scene.”

this book, puts you into the instant involvement of Eden's emotions; her pain, her shame and fear,  as well as the feeling that she’s been damaged beyond repair. times when she thinks she’s unlikely to ever be treated with respect and tenderness. 

*The author's resource note at the end and include the free hotline for the Rape, Abuse, & Incest National Network: 1-800-656-HOPE. If you need someone, please know help is available and confidential.

"i dont know who i am right now. but i know who im not. and i like that" - the way i used to be by amber smith

Book title: The Way I Used To Be
Author: Amber Smith

Trigger Warnings: this book does have discussions and depictions of rape as well as suicidal ideation.

This book was so beautiful and got me so mad and frustrated. It truly shows how across years how trauma can effect so many aspects of a persons life for years. I read this book in two sittings, and I was in awe.

Synopsis: Eden was always good at being good. Starting high school didn’t change who she was. But the night her brother’s best friend rapes her, Eden’s world capsizes.

What was once simple, is now complex. What Eden once loved—who she once loved—she now hates. What she thought she knew to be true, is now lies. Nothing makes sense anymore, and she knows she’s supposed to tell someone what happened but she can’t. So she buries it instead. And she buries the way she used to be.

Told in four parts—freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior year—this provocative debut reveals the deep cuts of trauma. But it also demonstrates one young woman’s strength as she navigates the disappointment and unbearable pains of adolescence, of first love and first heartbreak, of friendships broken and rebuilt, all while learning to embrace the power of survival she never knew she had hidden within her heart.

#thewayiusedtobe #thewayiusedtobebook #ambersmith #emotionalbook #mentalhealthawareness #metoo

⋆·˚ ༘ *the way i used to be by amber smith ★★★★☆ 4.75/5
the review and the slides contains spoilers !!!

first of all pls notice that this book contains a lot of triggers and the characters are all a bit toxic and with younger readers reading this book, this can have a very bad influence on them. ages 12+ should read this book, not any younger than that. also please before reading check the trigger warnings list first
this book discusses: sex*al ass*ult/ suicidal thoughts/ a lot of alc*hol consumption/ dr*gs/ underage s*x

now getting into the actual review. this book talks about eden who gets r*ped by her brother's bestfriend at the age of 13, doesn't tell anyone about it not even her family and how her journey is like after that traumatic experience. 
what I found is that this book is highly realistic. it shows how a single worst thing could just completely turn the tide of your whole life, it brings out something feral that you'd never imagined to be...
i really above all like the way how the author reinforced the fact that you yourself are the only person who could pick up your shattered pieces and mend it and that there are limitations for others.. throughout the whole book people try to help eden but they fail because as long as you don't open yourself to healing, people won't know how to support you and it might even drive them away. you have to let yourself grieve, break then mend and heal so you can accept the help offered to you.
i enjoyed reading all the parts of the book; they were all unique in their own way and how different eden's actors were in every part as she grew and as the emotions kept bottling up til the point of a breakdown, it gave me a new perspective and the self-sabotage was beautifully written.
as for the ending, I really wanted to see what happens with her friends but i can understand why it wasn't added. i think the author wanted to focus more on eden by the end instead of giving us the reactions and i respect that but i just felt like it was kind of rushed? like i expected bit more but i can see why some people love it. it was a the ending that leaves us with questions but content and hopeful. 

my dms are always open for you guys

TW: Rape, Sexual assault and harassment, substance abuse, bullying

Another tough read which is all I seem to be reading lately lol. I actually finished this book about a week ago but got caught up reading other stuff that I forgot to review it. “The Way I Used to Be” tells the story of Eden and her journey to put herself back together after being raped by a close family friend. The book is told in 4 parts, detailing her freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior years of high school. At its heart, it’s a story about how one event can change your entire life, and how hard it can be to pick up the pieces and move forward. 

I had a really good time reading this book, it definitely dealt with tough subject matter and had me crying on more than one occasion. Eden is a very relatable and likable protagonist who you can definitely relate to in a lot of ways. While some of the book feels a bit rushed, I definitely would still recommend it to anyone. 4.5/5⭐️ 

#thewayiusedtobe #thewayiusedtobebook

The Way I Used To Be by Amber Smith 
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️.5 / 5 
- TRIGGER WARNING - SA, Bullying, Substance Abuse.
This book is definitely very underrated. I read this book a few years ago and reread it very recently. Eden, is such a misunderstood character who only needed someone to truly see her. I was extremely bummed out by the ending but I understood that Eden needed to become her own savior and find herself again and fully heal. 
This book definitely means a lot to me <3 

“I don’t know who I am right now. But I know who I’m not. And I like that”.

the way i used to be - amber smith 

CW - rape (graphic), substance abuse
🖤🖤🖤

“the plan was to get better, to feel better, by any means. but i don’t feel better, i feel empty, empty and broken, still”
-

the way i used to be is told over the course of four years, following the night that eden was raped by her brother’s best friend. we see eden’s development through these years as she navigates through life, trying to get as far away from the girl she used to be as possible. this book explores trauma in an emotional and very real way.

while being focused solely on eden and her development throughout the years, this book isn’t very plot-driven, yet is still able to be engaging and spark really important discussions. 

eden is a very real, human character. we see her acting self-destructive, hurting those she loves, and putting herself in dangerous situations as her perception of the world changes. we also begin to see her take responsibility and begin the path of healing, which was an emotional end to the novel.

overall, this book was an important read and it was very well done, however due to its contents it was a little hard to read. i gave it 3/5 stars.

#booktok #bookstagram #books #reading #bookreview #thewayiusedtobe #thewayiusedtobebook

Guten Morgen friends🫶🏼
Es tut mir so leid, dass ich irgendwie so lange untergetaucht bin, aber ich hatte einfach keine Zeit😅
Ich hab in den letzten Wochen jetzt meinen Führerschein gemacht und bin jetzt finally freeee🥹
Seitdem hab ich auch endlich wieder mehr Zeit zum lesen, ich konnte mich davor irgendwie nicht so richtig konzentrieren…
Aber heute mal zu einem ganz besonderen Buch: the way I used to be.
Ich kann nur sagen: wenn ihr zerstört werden wollt, lest dieses Buch. Wenn nicht, lasst es lieber. Ich hab’s einfach geliebt. Die Handlungen von Eden waren gleichzeitig so krass, aber auch irgendwie so nachvollziehbar. Ich habe so mit ihr gefühlt und gelitten, es ist unfassbar😮‍💨
Die Geschichte ist wirklich schwer zu verdauen und definitiv nichts für schwache Nerven. Und obwohl ich das Buch vor knapp 2 Wochen beendet habe, löst es immer noch ein beklemmendes Gefühl in mir aus, wenn ich intensiver darüber nachdenke. Und das mit einem Buch zu schaffen, ist eine Kunst🤍
Hier einmal noch der Klappentext für euch: Eden was always good at being good. Starting high school didn’t change who she was. But the night her brother’s best friend rapes her, Eden’s world capsizes.

What was once simple, is now complex. What Eden once loved—who she once loved—she now hates. What she thought she knew to be true, is now lies. Nothing makes sense anymore, and she knows she’s supposed to tell someone what happened but she can’t. So she buries it instead. And she buries the way she used to be.

Told in four parts—freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior year—this provocative debut reveals the deep cuts of trauma. But it also demonstrates one young woman’s strength as she navigates the disappointment and unbearable pains of adolescence, of first love and first heartbreak, of friendships broken and rebuilt, and while learning to embrace a power of survival she never knew she had hidden within her heart.
*

This book hurt so bad. I had to stop multiple times & I cried ):

Talking about sexual assault is hard but extremely important. 

Despite being painful to read, and extremely triggering, seeing the effects of trauma unfold so intimately in a characters life just goes to illustrate how important seeking help is, and the effects of not.

Definitely recommend!

; 🕊

Hmmm. I really don’t know how to write the review of this book because it’s one of those books that you just want to finish so you’d move on to another book😅 
‘The Way I Used To Be’ is a book about s*xual assault.

The main characters is Eden McCrorey, Edy for short. She was a victim of rape when she was about twelve years old, by her brother's best friend, Kevin Armstrong.
She goes through high school believing she couldn’t confide in anyone about what had happened to her, which made her do a lot of unreasonable things that really got me pissed.
Though this book made me understand the trauma of those who had gone through the same, but I’d like to say that we shouldn’t allow our past rule our present. Your past can either make you or mar you, so choose which.

I only enjoyed reading the beginning and the end parts of the book. All through the middle, the only thing I felt was rage.

I will give it a 3⭐️
Have you read the book? I’d like to know your view in the comments🥰

#bookstagram #book #bookstagrammer #blackbookstagramtour #booknow #bookvibes #thewayiusedtobebook #bookrecommendations #bookreview #bookreader #novel #bookclubsinnigeria #booklovers #booklove #booklove #bookstagramfollowback #bookstagramcommunity

The way I used to be written by Amber Smith. 
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
This story looks at how trauma can affect your actions. How not talking about that trauma can eat at all of your healthy relationships. Also, how that trauma doesn’t give you an excuse to inflict pain on anyone else. 
A must read story. Check trigger warnings. 
But unfortunately no tears…. 😢 

#thewayiusedtobebook #thewayiusedtobe #ambersmith #fictionbooks #trauma #checktriggerwarnings #nomeansno🚫 #bookstagram #bookreview

💙 The Way I Used To Be 💙

♾/5

I knew that when I first decided to read this book that it was going to be a sad one and it was going to break my heart. What I didn’t know was that it would soon become one of my most favourite stand alone books that I have ever read!

Eden, precious Eden!🥺 what this girl had to experience at such a young age hurt! It really hurt! But the respect and love I had for her throughout the book was insane!

After a horrible event you see the aftermath and how this event affects Edens life throughout freshman, sophomore, junior and senior year. You see how she handles her relationships with her friends, future love interests and her family. You also get to see how she navigates her emotions.

There were many parts throughout the book where I related to Eden and her lack of trust! I understood what she was going through in parts of the book and how certain events can make you feel and act a certain way. This just made me love the book even more!

I feel that when you can relate to a book you just have this extra level of love and connection to it🥰

I loved Josh’s character and what he brought to the book. I know a lot of people didn’t like the ending but I thought it was fantastic!

You need to realise that Eden needed to find who she was on her own two feet and needed to work through her trauma by herself while having people there for her!

Overall this was a very very good book and I will forever hold it close to my heart! If you choose to read this book please look up the trigger warnings first!

I believe this book was wonderfully written🥰

<3 KC

i first read “The Way I Used to Be” back in April, but last night, i felt the need to re read it. this book is one of the most heartbreakingly beautiful things that i’ve ever read, and it’s so hard for me to put into words how i truly feel about it. it somehow broke my heart open and put it back together every chapter, and i’m so so happy i decided fo pick up this book when i did. i just wanted to hug Eden so tightly, and for so much of the book, i felt like i was walking that journey with her — which is exactly what i needed. (if you plan to read it: please check tws!!🤍)

The Way i used to be -Amber Smith✨

Klappentext
Eden was always good at being good. Starting high school didn’t change who she was. But the night her brother’s best friend rapes her, Eden’s world capsizes. 
What was once simple, is now complex. What Eden once loved—who she once loved—she now hates. What she thought she knew to be true, is now lies. Nothing makes sense anymore, and she knows she’s supposed to tell someone what happened but she can’t. So she buries it instead. And she buries the way she used to be. 
Told in four parts—freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior year—this provocative debut reveals the deep cuts of trauma. But it also demonstrates one young woman’s strength as she navigates the disappointment and unbearable pains of adolescence, of first love and first heartbreak, of friendships broken and rebuilt, all while learning to embrace the power of survival she never knew she had hidden within her heart. 

Ich hatte emotional schon sehr große Erwartungen an das Buch, hab mich eventuell auch etwas für Tiktok beeinflussen lassen😂 Das Buch ist definitiv emotional, keine Frage, habe es mir noch etwas intensiver vorgestellt. 
Der Schreibstil war super angenehm und flüssig zu lesen. Ich kann das Buch aufjedenfall empfehlen, auch für jüngere, die gerne ernste Themen mögen, da die Protagonistin auch noch relativ jung ist, was natürlich sehr sehr schrecklich ist😢
Eden durchläuft im Buch eine sehr große Veränderung, aufgrund der Umstände, die sie quasi dazu führen. Es geht um ein junges Mädchen, welches sehr viel scheiße erlebt und langsam daran zerbricht. Eine kleine, sehr realistische Liebesgeschichte gibt es im Buch, der Fokus liegt jedoch auf Eden und ihrer Geschichte🥰
Gegen Ende fand ich alles total traurig und schwer. Man sollte sich aufjedenfall vor Beginn die Triggerwahrnung durchlesen und sich, vorallem wenn man jünger ist, nur mit dem Thema beschäftigen, wenn es einen nicht zu sehr belastet.
Große Empfehlung! Hätte mir trotzdem etwas mehr Intensivität gewünscht🥰

4,5/5⭐️

TRIGGER WARNING: violación/asalto sexual, Abuso de sustancias y Depresión.

SINOPSIS: Tu me crees ¿verdad?

 Eden siempre fue buena en ser buena. Comenzar la escuela secundaria no cambió su esencia. Pero una noche todo cambia y el mundo de Eden da un vuelco. Lo que antes era simple, ahora es complejo. Lo que Eden una vez amó, a quien una vez amó, ahora lo odia. Lo que ella pensó que sabía que era verdad, ahora son mentiras. Ya nada tiene sentido, y sabe que se supone que debe contarle a alguien lo que sucedió, pero no puede. Así que en su lugar, lo entierra, y entierra la forma en que solía ser. Contada en cuatro partes: primer año, segundo, tercer y último año, este provocativo debut revela los profundos cortes del trauma. Pero también demuestra la fortaleza de una mujer joven mientras navega por la decepción y los dolores insoportables de la adolescencia, el primer amor y el primer desamor, las amistades rotas y reconstruidas, y mientras, aprende a abrazar un poder de supervivencia que nunca supo que tenía escondido dentro de su corazón.

MI OPINIÓN:
ESTE LIBRO ME DESTROZA.
Me duele, me quema y me lastima.
Empecemos por Eden, quiero abrazarla y no dejarla ir nunca.
Odio a Kevin, nunca creí que pudiese odiar tanto a un personaje y estoy feliz con como se dieron las cosas para él al final.
Josh. Omg Josh quiero besarle y pegarle, no se en que orden.
Josh es todo lo que está bien en este mundo. Quiero. No. NECESITO un Josh.
Necesito con urgencia saber donde puedo comprarme un nuevo novio.
Si bien el romance es importante, no es lo MAS importante a lo largo de toda la trama.
Todas podríamos ser Eden, y es lo que más duele y hace que conectes con la historia.
Definitivamente una de las mejores lecturas del año.
5/5💫

Book Review!!
“The Way I Used To Be” 

4.5/5 

This book broke me. It showed me how to see life differently. I’m so glad that I read this book. 

This book follows a girl named Eden throughout high school. But her second semester starts of with a tragic event. That’s where the story starts.

#bookstagram #booktok #bookrecommendations #bookreview #bookstagrammer #thewayiusedtobebook

SINOPSIS:
¿Por qué no me dejas amarte?
Kristen Petersen no hace drama, lucha hasta la muerte por sus amigos y no tiene lugar en su vida para hombres que simplemente no la entienden. También guarda un gran secreto: se enfrenta a un procedimiento médicamente necesario que le impedirá tener hijos. Planificar la boda de su mejor amiga es algo agridulce para Kristen, especialmente cuando conoce al padrino, Josh Copeland. Él es divertido, sexy, nunca se ofende por su amplia racha de sarcasmo, y siempre tiene lista una enchilada de pollo a la mano para curar su hambre. Incluso su perro, Stuntman Mike, lo adora. El único problema: Josh quiere una gran familia algún día. Kristen sabe que él estaría mejor con otra persona, pero a medida que crece su atracción, es cada vez más difícil mantenerlo a distancia.

MI OPINIÓN:
Tenemos nuevo novio literariooo. 
Estoy enamorada de Josh. Él es todo lo que está bien en esta vida y me hizo preguntarme donde puedo ir y correr a comprarlo.
Amé esta rom com, la primera de esta saga escrita por Abby. 
Si bien Kris me pareció un poco cabeza dura, me divertí mucho con su sarcasmo y forma de ser.
Si te gusta el romance del tipo no eres tu, soy yo y mi gran cabezota entonces este es tu libro.
4/5💫

Sinopsis: 
¿Quién nunca le pidió ayuda a su amigo para perder la virginidad?

Keely tiene dieciocho años, vive en una pequeña ciudad y va al instituto con el mismo grupo de personas desde la guardería. Cuando una de sus amigas, la popular Danielle, pierde la virginidad en su fiesta de cumpleaños, Keely piensa que es la única virgen de la clase y esto empieza a preocuparle. Entonces, un joven universitario increíblemente atractivo empieza a interesarse por ella. Pero ¿qué pasará cuando se entere de que nunca «lo ha hecho»? Para que es no ocurra, Keely traza un plan casi perfecto: pedirle ayuda a Andrew, su mejor amigo, quien puede enseñarle algunos truquillos y prepararla para el gran momento. El plan funcionará mientras sean, por supuesto, amigos, solo amigos. Aunque lo que Keely no sabe es que los planes, a veces, no salen como una espera.

La gente siempre dice: «Espera a estar preparada». Pero ¿cómo sabes cuándo lo estás? Si acostarte con alguien significa exponerte a un corazón roto, al ridículo o al dolor, no sé si estaré preparada algún día.

MI OPINIÓN:
Me gustó mucho este libro,  es muy dulce y si te gustan los clichés con un poco de spicy sobre mejores amigos que se lanzan miraditas, este definitivamente es tu momento de leerlo.
Si bien quise darle con la silla a Andrew y a Keely un par de veces, la historia en general es muy divertida y rápida de leer.
Andrew es mi nuevo novio del momento.
4/5💫

This was such an easy read but it took me more than I planned to finish reading. It was because I knew I was going to get heartbroken and I was procrastinating. So today, solely for this reason I took my book with me and went to a coffee shop, sat at a table that was directly under the sun and I finished this book. Honestly I think it was not the best decision to read the last part of the book in public because I tried very hard to hold my tears. 
•
Reading this book was a different experience. It proves to you how one messed up person can cause a chain reaction and ruin bunch of people’s lives. I felt so much and I think that is because the author expressed feelings so genuinely. At times I was frustrated with the heroine and at times I was frustrated with other characters in the book. And during this the author never gave me a chance to be angry with a character more than a few pages. Her writing gives you so much insight on how all of the characters feel and you find yourself empathising even with the characters you don’t want to empathise. Except the antihero of this book. In the book his reasoning for being this way is briefly mentioned but never in detail. I can’t empathise with him. I. Will. Not.
•
CW: this book talks about sexual assault in detail and focuses on Heroine’s inner struggles/ feelings after she was sexually assaulted. 
•
The things this book thought me and made me remember:

Reach out to people. Talk to professionals. And when you are strong enough, talk about it so others can learn from you and maybe also find the courage to speak up. 

Especially tell the ones who want to ignore your struggles. Make them uncomfortable. Don’t let them act like everything is okay. Particularly, if you are form a culture in which people advise you to take bunch of precautions, who ask you why you were wearing what you were wearing and why were you out so late. Don’t. Let. Them. 

And lastly if you are a parent, always remind your kids that you are their safe space. That there is nothing in this world that would diminish your love for them. I was a lucky kid and I still am because there wasn’t one moment I felt like my mother wasn’t on my side.
